column11: Review Text

Food below average Costs above average Atmosphere not very good Entrance reminds of a building site  could do with some cheering up Puddings and deserts need improving. I personally cannot recommend this place. If you want Atmosphere,  happening scene and tasty food. Try the Kingsbury. Go for th the Evening Buffet. Tell them a happy guest recommend them Room 301
Nice viewing spot from the tallest self-supported structure in South Asia. A fee to enter but no good if raining or even drizzling. Unique appearance from the outside as well.

column8: Amazing Views from Colombo Lotus Tower
column11: Visited Colombo Lotus Tower with my family and had an incredible experience! The 360¬∞ panoramic view from the tallest point in Colombo is absolutely stunning. The best time to visit is between 5:00 PM and 6:00 PM so you can enjoy the breathtaking sunset. A must-see landmark when in Colombo.. Ticket fee Adults Local (Rs. 500) / Foreign (USD 20)

column8: Nice South/Southeast Asian Buffet with a View
column11: This Review is solely for the Blue Orbit Citrus Restaurant. Make Reservations directly with the Restaurant,  the Buffet is roughly 20-30 dollars per adult, where I found some third party apps charging close to 60 USD per adult! Making a reservation was a little hard to understand,  but a text and a call and a little faith that they saved your reservation and you are in there,  they give a window, and not a specific time which took me a second to pick up on. When you arrive, dont be intimidated if there is a wrap around line outside, that line is for the observation deck. Just inform an attendant that you made a reservation and they will walk you directly to the elevator (making you feel a little bad for skipping the line, but also like a badass VIP) The windows closest to the windows are for couples only and do not rotate, but there is a rotating platform for the rest of the tables that my kids enjoyed. The view is amazing, we went at night so the lights were pretty, but I bet seeing it in the day is also great. The food was good, a mix of Sri Lankan, Indian and Chinese all in one Buffet.

column8: Observation deck is closed for rain or drizzle
column11: Observation deck is closed when it‚Äôs raining, even for drizzle. I gave it the low rating because there is no warning or disclaimer by the site or timely status update when the observation deck is closed due to rain. There could even be a sign posted at the entrance when the deck is closed.

column8: Nice views, disappointing experience but has more potential
column11: It was nice to see the Lotus Tower closely. Despite only been built a few years ago, the inside is already looking dated and old. The bathrooms are not in great condition and there are a few empty shops on the ground floor. The lift was not particularly modern looking either. However, it was nice seeing the views from the top and identify some of the landmarks. Although many of the signs do not actually line up with the landmark and is actually far to the left or right making it difficult to find them. Great to have this for locals as the only viewing tower in the country. However, there was nothing else of interest there. They still charged full price despite the Pixel Bloom under renovation for a couple of days (this was not explained until walking around aimlessly trying to find it). Okay experience but have seen plenty of other observation decks done a lot better and made more interesting. Hopefully improvements will be made to make this a focal attraction in Colombo in the future.

We first visit the deck, personel was unfriendly and grumpy. But the views were great. The extra animation were very boring and childish. Later we visit the restaurant, friendly personal and great food.
This is one of the Rip off place charging for people who has a passport please try to avoid even some of the workers not respectfull so i avoid this place with family

column8: Iconic Lotus Tower with great observation deck
column11: Aptly named Lotus Tower stands at a height of 351.5 meters (1,153 feet). It is an iconic tower in the city visible from afar. Completed in 2019, it serves various purposes, including communication and observation, as well as leisure facilities. An entry fee charged for going up to the observation gallery. In between you can find restaurants, supermarket and food court. Not very crowded, suggest visit early morning . Nice views of city from gallery. You can take a break at one of the food outlets

The Lotus Tower in the Sri Lankan capital of Colombo is a 350-meter-tall television tower. The tower is the tallest structure in Sri Lanka, one of the tallest structures in Asia, and also one of the tallest television towers in the world. The structure has become a prominent landmark and tourist attraction in Colombo. The Lotus Tower of Colombo, Sri Lanka's capital, is a 350-meter-high television tower. The tower is the tallest structure in Sri Lanka, one of the tallest in Asia and also one of the tallest television towers in the world. The structure became a prominent landmark and landmark of Colombo.

I am a American resident born and bred in Sri Lanka who left at the age of 27. We were visiting SL and wanted to experience the new attraction which was not open during my last visit in 2019. The price was displayed as 500 SLRupees to enter. When approached to purchase tickets counter wanted to charge us $20 equal to 6000 rupees which is ridiculously high even for a foreigner visiting because I did not have a Sri Lanka ID card. We left without buying the tickets. Be reasonable for ex Sri Lankan who are interested in seeing new additions in the motherland.

find the exit. We requested the exit from the guest relations hostess.(Muslim lady in blue suit.) She directed me to my destination. The first time, I didn't hear the way. When I asked a second time, her body language was quite harsh. The facial expressions were pretty awful.

The first thing we did after landing in Colombo was visit the Tower, a major attraction in the city. The view from the top is fantastic, and the crowd management is well organised. The Pixel Show is enjoyable for small kids. Although the tickets are pretty expensive, they're worth visiting at least once. However, the washrooms on the ground level need some upkeep. Overall, I would recommend visiting! üëå

This was one of the first things we did when we landed in Colombo, and it was such a great way to begin seeing the city. The views from the top are really beautiful, and on a clear day, you can really see quite far. The Pixel experience was closed the day we were there, but a great stop if you want to see Colombo from the sky!

The Lotus Tower is a stunning architectural marvel that offers breathtaking city views from its observation deck. Its iconic lotus-inspired design is a treat to the eyes, day and night. The Pixel Bloom experience adds a magical touch, blending art and technology with interactive, vibrant digital displays that captivate visitors of all ages. With excellent facilities and friendly staff, it‚Äôs a must-visit for anyone seeking a mix of beauty, creativity, and innovation. Perfect for both locals and tourists!
It was a windy evening when we had visited. Because of cloudiness the sunset was not as expected. However, great view of Colombo from the observation deck.

Colombo Lotus Tower The Colombo Lotus Tower, standing proudly in the heart of Colombo, is South Asia‚Äôs tallest self-supported structure and Sri Lanka‚Äôs tallest skyscraper, reaching an impressive height of 356 meters (1168 feet). Designed to resemble a lotus blossom, a symbol of purity and renewal, this iconic structure reflects the blend of tradition and modernity in Sri Lanka. With construction initiated in 2012, the tower was meticulously crafted over a decade and opened to the public on 15th September 2022, marking a new chapter in Sri Lanka‚Äôs architectural and technological advancement. Situated along the banks of Beira Lake, the Colombo Lotus Tower is a landmark visible from far beyond the city limits, drawing thousands of visitors each month who come to experience its panoramic observation deck, cutting-edge technology, and entertainment facilities. The tower offers a 360-degree view of Colombo, the Indian Ocean, and the lush landscapes that extend inland, making it a prime spot for sightseeing, photography, and cultural immersion.
Beautiful view top of lotus tower, but ticket price higher than we thought. Only lift up & down, No any function at top at that day.
Perfect accomodation! The room service was exceptional! People like Sakila work really hard for the guests to have a dreamy experience!
The view is amazing, best tune to go is in the evening to see sunset...school visits happen, so you got to be lucky to go when it's not crowded. Very well managed inside.

Appreciate foreign tourists extra cost but that's ok for us, not so for those with low wages or low income countries. Observation Deck has a good view over the city. Place cards on important sites but would be helpful if showed on a wider map to help spotting. Did the digital experience after which was fun and nice quick history too from Portuguese invasion onwards then more about colombo before doing interactive part. Worth it even though yiu can do something similar in most capitals and big cities nowadays

I thoroughly enjoyed my visit here. I went early and was in the first lift up ~ there were very few people around at that time. Despite it being a little hazy the views were still great and the haze only affected things in the distance which wouldn't have been very visible anyway. For me it was certainly worth the 6000 /= to go up there.

Terrible and ugly experience with tickets counter staffer. Impolite lack of customer service full on attitude. I am local visitor with my wife and daughter even I was provided my National ID still keep asking all of ours passports. Because of I we were well dressed staffer decided by her own mindset that we are foreign visitors. We just turned around and went back with disgusting experience.

We went with the children of two families and had a great time. The views from the top were breathtaking, offering a 360-degree panorama of the city. Additionally, they have a digital gallery, panoramic restaurants, shops, and a boardwalk on the ground floor. There‚Äôs a good selection of food stalls, and the place feels safe for families and friends.

The Lotus Tower, also known as the Colombo Lotus Tower, is 351.5 meters high  It has become a symbolic landmark for the country. Situated on 320 McCallum Rd, Colombo.  You can go up, the tower.  It stands out from the crowd and can be seen from many points in the city.  An amazing structure.  Best seen at night from a distance so you can see the lights changing colour.

Grand attractive place. Well organised. Neck wrenching tall. Money making enterprise. Very expensive tickets. Was charged full rate despite 50% of service not being available (closed due to works). Good views from top with helpful diagrams. Take your time at top. Looks better at night from a distance. Lots of eateries at base on exiting.

I‚Äôll start with the lift/elevator journey back down‚Ä¶my husband‚Äôs exact words: ‚ÄúWas that it??‚Äù Before entering, we took fab ground level photos of the tower, as well as the ‚ÄòColumbo phone box‚Äô outside - that was the best bit (which can be done for free). Enter (as a tourist) and expect, as others have said, to pay 20USD. This might not seem much when you compare it to the CN Tower in Toronto or the Burj Khalifa in Dubai - some might say ‚Äòit‚Äôs all relative‚Äô (on this occasion it‚Äôs not‚Ä¶) So‚Ä¶you are ushered past the ticket counter for locals, which is outside, enter the building and buy your 20USD tourist ticket. Go to the lift/elevator, and travel in an enclosed box for 29 floors. Exit. Walk around the tower viewing platform, taking views in/ taking photos as you like and after those 5-10mins have passed, return to the enclosed box to descend 29 floors as you think to yourself ‚ÄúWas that it??‚Äù (‚Ä¶ and your partner says it out loud‚Ä¶)

Visited the Colombo Lotus Tower on a day visit in Colombo. So surprised they charge ¬£16 per per person if your foreign and ¬£1.35 if your a local! Can you imagine if we did that in the UK?! Even though you so much more you don‚Äôt get any benefit, still the same queue, no priority or anything. The pixel show is a scam, it‚Äôs a simple array of lights whilst waiting for the elevator. Views were nice, definitely wouldn‚Äôt go if it was cloudy. Wouldn‚Äôt bother wasting time here. Nice to take pictures of the tower from around the city.
Beautiful view from the 29th floor over Colombo. Afterwards you can attend a presentation about the origins of SriLanka. This shows our VOC time.
We visited with friends, it‚Äôs quite an amazing view from up there of the whole city‚Ä¶. And good food too.   The floor rotates but not scary üòù
Prices are high that is 20 USD per tourist otherwise a top view of Colombo is seen so not so value for money as per my opinion

Tourist trap!!!!!!! It was way too expensive and there was nothing that was unique or interesting or remotely fun about this. If you really want to see Colombo from top, you could rather go to Sky lounge- Kingsbury or any other rooftop restaurants because this was $20 for international tourist and was just just seeing the city from top. 4/10

The Lotus Tower stands as the tallest single-supported structure in Southeast Asia and is a true architectural marvel in Colombo. While there‚Äôs an entrance fee of $20, the experience of ascending to the top is absolutely worth it. On a clear, sunny day, you‚Äôre treated to a breathtaking 360-degree panoramic view of Colombo, including a stunning bird‚Äôs-eye view of the main railway station and the city‚Äôs sprawling landscape. The tower is not only an iconic landmark but also a testament to modern engineering and design. Whether you‚Äôre a local or a visitor, the Lotus Tower is a must-visit destination for its unparalleled views and unique experience. Don‚Äôt miss the chance to see Colombo from this incredible vantage point!

I visited the Lotus Tower at night, and it was a truly remarkable experience. The view of Colombo‚Äôs night skyline from the top was breathtaking, with the city lights creating a mesmerizing scene. The Pixel Boom attraction was incredibly unique and added a fun and modern touch to the visit. It‚Äôs something both kids and adults can enjoy. Additionally, the play area for kids was well-designed, making it a great family-friendly destination. For Sri Lankans, this is a special and unique experience that highlights the beauty of the country. For foreigners, it offers a fantastic perspective of Colombo from the sky. A must-visit spot if you‚Äôre in Sri Lanka!

We went to the Lotus Tower in Colombo in the evening. It is indeed a unique landmark and the tallest tower in South Asia, offering spectacular views of the city and the surrounding coastline. It is very beautiful at night.

The Colombo Lotus Tower is a fantastic family-friendly destination, especially for kids. The observation deck offers stunning views of the city, and kids can enjoy the fun, interactive exhibits at the Sky Lounge. The glass-floored viewing platform is a thrilling experience for children, while the elevators with their light shows are a hit. The tower also features a variety of dining options, making it a great spot for a family outing. A must-visit for those with children in Colombo!
Great view from the restaurant but the food was below average. What made it worse was all of us got upset stomachs the next morning.

Heights Tower in the Colombo and can explore the wide area of views from high level deck. and restaurant also there , we can walk around 360 and see the nice view of mother Srilanka. and this is must visit place if you travel around colombo. ticket price is LKR 500 per local adult, and pixcelboom also very interesting with magical light works

column7: Ras Al Khaimah, United Arab Emirates
column11: Sri Lanka still employs a two-tier pricing system, which many tourists find frustrating. For instance, I recently observed 20‚Äì30 foreigners choosing not to pay the higher rates, while just as many expressed dissatisfaction on their way out. It raises the question: is this approach sustainable in today‚Äôs global tourism market? I had walked from Galle Face and decided to rest, but the experience left me reflecting on how this outdated pricing system affects Sri Lanka's appeal. Tourists increasingly share their experiences online, and negative feedback can deter potential visitors. As tourism evolves, Sri Lanka should consider modernizing its policies. A fair pricing system could significantly enhance the visitor experience, encouraging return visits and bolstering the country's reputation. Hopefully, as new generations step into leadership, they'll prioritize more inclusive and progressive approaches to tourism that benefit both visitors and the local economy. The price for this attraction is far too high and certainly not worth the money or a pleasant experience.

The management and the staff at the rooftop were very rude and aggressive. They can say the  rules in a polite way. They were very harsh and treating us as beggars. I know bad incident happened recently but for that you cannot treat everybody rudely . You all should mind your respect. Treat others with some humanity. End of the day we paid our money and visited your place. We did not come for free .

After looking at this beautiful building spectacle from our hotel room for several days and finding out it has a revolving restaurant, we decided to make the visit.. Firstly we were over charged by a Tuk Tuk driver for a 400 lkr journey where the driver tried to charge us 5000lkr. Upon arriving at the Lotus Tower we entered the queue and paid a fee of 11574lkr to get tickets to enter. This is 20$ us each for 2. We entered the building through an airport style security bag scan and then got in a queue for the lifts. Whilst presenting our tickets we asked if this was the way to the restaurant bar to which the answer was yes and our ticket stubs were torn so we proceeded with all the other guests to the lifts which took us directly to the top floor viewing point. Not knowing where the bar actually was we walked around looking for the bar restaurant to be told we had to go back to reception and then book on the 1st floor. We ventured back down to the ground floor and asked the staff about the  restaurant and we were told the ticket wasn't needed for entry to the restaurant and that it was for the digital art experience on the ground floor and viewing point only. By this point we were 20 mins in which is how long it took to get to the top and bottom again without stopping including queues. After explaining that we didn't realise we didn't need a ticket to A enter the building as this  is far from obvious to a foreign traveller and B we certainly wouldn't have purchased a ticket for a digital exhibition we had no interest in seeing. No we're a little confused so we asked for help and explained we don't want the exhibition or viewing point as there's plenty to be seen from a revolving restaurant anyway. The staff then laughed at us for being stupid foreigners who made a mistake and actually smiled the upset we got for buying something we don't use or need, further they weren't prepared to offer a refund and allow us to spend the money in the restaurant as it's apparently a separate business to the tower attractions. Standing in the lobby trying to explain our mistake made no difference to the staff and no matter who we spoke to on this subject we were treated with total disrespect and laughter at our mistake only to be told it's company policy not to offer refunds. Like we are trying to take something from them. We both found it rude and inconsiderate. We've spent plenty of money in Sri Lanka since visiting and tipped well everyone we visit. Sri Lanka as a whole we've found completely amazing. However 2 days from the end of our trip to be insulated and worse laughed at for an honest mistake was awful. Sadly we left not only without using the tickets or visiting the restaurant bar. What's more sad is that we couldn't even give the tickets to another couple outside as the first thing they do when you get in is tear the stub. Terrible experience, awful attitude from staff. Extremely disappointed.

Great spot in Colombo, must visit! We tried the Blue Orbit restaurant in Level 27, which is a rotating restaurant with international buffet, variety of options for all tastes. The experience was amazing and I highly recommend it for anyone passing by Colombo, the view is stunning and it costs 9000 Sri Lankan rupees per person.

very beautiful. good to click pictures. The tourists need to pay 10 times more than the locals i.e. approx. USD 20-25 / person. Does not justify the value. Still you can visit the ground floor and click pictures at the backyard (lake facing). Apparently the money collected by the tower goes to some third party firm (Chinese perhaps) as a part of some financial deal.

I always head to the tallest building of any city I visit. Having been to Colombo many times and seen the Lotus Tower being constructed I was pleased to be able to experience it for the first time. The cost for me and my 2 Sri Lankan friends was $20 and it was possible to pay by card Our visit was on a Saturday morning so there were lots of people. but it didn't take too long to buy tickets and the queue for the lift to the 30th floor viewing platform was not too long. A reasonably clear day it was possible to view the whole of the city and the areas beyond On the ground floor we were most impressed by the Pixel Bloom Exhibition. This provided a brief history of Sri  Lanka and Colombo and also included an interactive light experience Definitely worth the visit
Lotus tower also  referred to as colombo lotus tower,is a 351.5 M tall tower,located in colombo,Sri Lanka.its has been a symbolic landmark of srilanka.

the tower was good but the experience with the entrance staff (a young woman was very bad). she was not at all helpful inspite of telling her we had an advance ticket. how does one promote  tourism if you place people at the entrance gate itself

Not the best tower in the world but for Sri Lanka, I enjoyed it being up in the viewing platform looking over Colombo. As for the videos in the theatres, though childlike, I enjoyed them and learnt some. Loved it all. Would have liked to go up to the dining room for a look see but no, you need to book a table to be able to go up.

Nice experience and certainly the best in Colombo, too chaotic and busy to be seen in a short time on foot. Yes you get to the 29th floor by elevator and if you are lucky and the sky is clear, you can also see the mountains. The city from above looks bigger than I imagined and all the main points are visible The color of the deep green lake below gives a breathtaking view Cost for tourists including pixel bloom 20$ The pixel boom is a kind of virtual reality (not very virtual). At the entrance a very cute cartoon tells the story of Columbus, followed by three other rooms with other surprises
Views were nice BUT  it's another 1 of those places where tourists and charged ridiculous amounts compared to locals, I didn't see 1 other tourist
It‚Äôs a good viewpoint, with decent views over Colombo. Nothing overly special to be frank,  although sunset was spectacular! You could find yourself a rooftop bar instead üòä
The views were amazing but the pixel bloom was beautiful but small. The shops are also good but expensive. If you want to see Colombo, then the lotus tower won't disappoint.

Adding a new experience to the Sri Lankan landscape, the tallest self-supported structure in South Asia and the tallest skyscraper in the country, the Lotus Tower is the ultimate culmination of ingenuity and innovation.¬†Rising towards Colombo‚Äôs skyline the Nelum Kuluna is an iconic landmark that reflects the spirit of a nation.

It is quite nice experience to go to the top since can see greater Colombo area. I am not sure to which extent we could see since I am not familiar with many of the surroundings! I expected more active lobby area with so many things, but it was quite empty, just a few cafes/ restaurants were in. Seems still need to organize the lobby area as I seen some areas used for storage.
I don't think it's worth paying that much money to climb the tower. There are plenty of hotels that offer free rooftops and you can climb up and have a panoramic view of the city

As a tour guide, I‚Äôm always excited to showcase the Colombo Lotus Tower, a true gem of Sri Lanka‚Äôs skyline. Standing tall at 350 meters, this architectural marvel offers breathtaking panoramic views of the city and beyond. Visitors are often captivated by the striking lotus flower design and the state-of-the-art observation deck, where you can see Colombo‚Äôs vibrant cityscape and the Indian Ocean stretching out to the horizon. The tower also features a variety of dining options and entertainment facilities, making it a fantastic destination for both sightseeing and relaxation. It‚Äôs always rewarding to see my guests marvel at this landmark and appreciate its unique blend of modernity and cultural symbolism. The Colombo Lotus Tower is definitely a highlight of any tour and a must-visit for anyone exploring Sri Lanka‚Äôs capital.
A definite must do in Colombo. Go to observation deck (for a fee) to get panoramic view of the city. Observation deck includes directions to look for historic sights.

This place is not worth it, they are charging 6000 rupees for foreigners to see literally nothing in the tower why would you pay 6000 rupees for a view per person. The service is horrible the lady at the front desk for the ticket entrance was unwelcoming. They are scamming foreigners for literally nothing just because they think they can take money off of tourists. DO NOT WASTE YOUR TIME OR MONEY.

Great views from the top of this modern newly constructed tower. Entry cost of $20 pp. breezy at top but this was a light relief to the heat and humidity of the city. Good security. Some other activities mainly aimed to entertain kids but just visited for views due to available time.

Great 360¬∞ view of the city. The movies in the museum are for children but I could learn the history. Good place to check the direction I visited and reflect on my trip. When I visited, local elementary school students were visiting for a school event. It was very funny to see them all enjoying the scenery, and it made me happy as well.

Great views of the city and Indian Ocean as you‚Äôd expect with brief information on the obs deck. There is an interactive element at ground level which does a good job of summarising Colombo‚Äôs history and tower location, if not a little touristy and gimmicky afterwards.

We visited the Lotus tower and it was great. Being the highest observation tower in South Asia and being on top 20 towers in the world, this is a must visit if you're in Colombo. The first thing you notice is the differential ticket pricing for tourists vs locals which is a typical Sri Lankan process. The tour all the way to the observation deck is well organised with a stopover at a display which shows some details about the tower. Then off to the elevator that takes you up to level 29 where the observation deck is. The day was very clear so we could see all the way down towards central Sri Lanka and all suburbs of Colombo. It also provides good views of port city currently under construction. Overall a highly recommended visit if you're in Colombo.

Lotus tower is a symbolic landmark in the city of Colombo. It has a height of more than 350 metres. This is the tallest tower in South Asia. There is an observation deck on the top which one can visit post buying a ticket of USD 20. Below the observation deck, the tower also has a beautiful revolving restaurant, however one has to pre-book the same. Would highly recommend a visit.
The Lotus Tower is more beautiful on the outside than on the inside. However, the observation deck offers 360-degree views of Colombo.
